fields.description: Sometimes you want to partly cherry pick. The most common way is to use a cherry pick without a direct commit. This is possible with regular git (use git cherry-pick *-n*).
fields.summary: Allow 'cherry-pick' without commit

fields.description: Hi there, I will love that the checkbox in the toolbar button for "stash" does remember my last selection because each time I hit it, I need to select it for "keep changes", I think it will improve flow if this checkbox remember what it was the last time, so you only switch it when necessary and keep going.
fields.summary: Remember last selection on stash checkbox

fields.description:
On some of my repositories, the badge on the push button never updates (after commiting)
I verified that "Check Default remotes" is on (as stated, some of the repos do have the badge)
And even tried "Refresh Remote Status"
The remote is indicated as behind in the graph, but no badge to indicate I need to push

(tried here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/22651777/answers/23757887 got a recommendation to open a bug report)
fields.summary: SourceTree push badge isn't showing

fields.description:
SourceTree hangs on me constantly while diffing. Steps to repro:

1. Pretend like you are doing a code review with someone and diff each file in a commit.
2. Repeat.
3. SourceTree will eventually hang.

This probably happens to me about 3-6 times a day. It's absolutely infuriating. I know I've had an email exchange about this, but couldn't find a bug when I searched the db.

Anyhow, please let me know if there is anything I can do to help you track down this bug.
fields.summary: Sourcetree hangs on me all the time when diffing

fields.description:
- Repository settings...
- Remotes Add
- URL/Path Right Side Button
- Create New Repository...
- Select Bitbucket account
- Select Private/Git
- Create repository
- Freeze

* I can create GitHub remote repo. mm...
fields.summary: Freeze always when create remote Bitbucket git repo

fields.description:
Hi,

I'm not sure if this should be considered a bug or a feature request so I've marked it as a bug for now.  I've noticed that when I open SourceTree and no changes have been made, the app defaults to the Log view.  Is there any way to change this functionality to open whatever the last view was?  I'm a big fan of remembering state :)

Thanks!
fields.summary: Remember view

fields.description:
When searching through commit messages, it is really hard to find anything.

For example, a search for e.g. "database backup" returns zero matches, but it would be incredibly useful if it would match commit messages such as:
_"Backup databases before we start migration"_

Right now though, it will only match if it finds "database backup" precisely in the string which is a bit frustrating.
fields.summary: Search commit messages should search for occurences of the string in the entire message

fields.description: There were instructions there out there how to clean out one's profile from SourceTree's folders on Mac and Windows. Can this please be implemented as a "Logout" button feature so one's profile (login keys, credentials, global settings, bookmarks, etc.) are saved somewhere and allow another person to "login" with their own? Thanks! basically, add a button to "Logout" (and conversely "Log in") to do [this|https://confluence.atlassian.com/sourcetreekb/how-to-wipe-sourcetree-preferences-412484640.html] and its reverse. Especially useful when SourceTree is run on shared group accounts among multiple users so one can commit changes under their own name.
fields.summary: "Logout" feature for SourceTree (both OS X and Windows)

fields.description:
While using submodules in Sourcetree 2.0.3 and 2.0.4, when looking at the sidebar at the list of submodules, there was a [bracketed] reference to the commit or branch that the submodule was pointing to. 

However, in 2.0.5.2 this feature appears to have been removed.
fields.summary: Submodule display in sidebar has lost commit reference in 2.0.5

fields.description:
Users who want to push and clone with the Git LFS server will face a problem:

SourceTree has no mechanism to create a prompt for an authentication for Git LFS; it will only work if the Git LFS credentials are stored in the Git credential helper.

In Git's command line, however, this is not an issue; users are immediately prompted to insert username and password.
fields.summary: Request for Git LFS support.

fields.description: When using the stash feature, you have an option to keep the files untouched by the operation. However no matter what you chose with that checkbox, your uncommited changes will be reset.
fields.summary: Stash's keep staged changes seems broken.

fields.description:
I managed to reproduce this by:

1) Registering a license in my.atlassian.com with the password itself having quotes, similar to this format:

"password"

2) Registering SourceTree with the email and password of the license fails due to the password format, saying "Authorisation Failed: Parser failed with error":

!registration.png|thumbnail!

User has to click "forgot your password", change it to a password that didn't contain quotes, register it using the new password, then change my password back.

Do note that logging into my.atlassian.com works fine with the quotes; it's just SourceTree not accepting the password.
fields.summary: Registration fails if password has a quote symbol, produces error message "Authorisation Failed: Parser failed with error"

fields.description:
*Step to reproduce:*
1) Create and checkout a branch named 'someFunc'
2) Commit into the 'someFunc' branch
3) Create a tag named 'someFunc' for the commit
4) Merge the 'someFunc' branch to the master branch
5) Somehow, the tag 'someFunc' got merged into master branch instead.
fields.summary: Merging a branch to master when there is a tag which is the same name with the branch will merge the tag to the master
Should be able to create a bare repo and then clone it

fields.description:
Auto and manual refresh remote status does not show up status counters in sidebar if I setup SourceTree to use the system git from /opt/local/bin/git ([Macports|https://www.macports.org]) version 2.4.3.

If I set back to embedded git (v2.2.1), then it works. I would expect this feature to work with the newer external git as well.
fields.summary: Refresh remote status not working if using external/system git binary

fields.description:
Typo is in the "Allgemein" (General) tab of the Applicaiton Preferences.

See attachment.

I think
"Wähle alle Dateien bei einem Comic"

should be
"Wähle alle Dateien bei einem *Commit*"
fields.summary: Typo in German translation in Preferences Pane

fields.description:
Hello,

In order to better keep developers informed when their Git clients are out of sync with the server, i.e. PULL's available, pull requests, etc. It would be great if you could use the remote/push notification technology to notify clients when Stash gets changes.  Just like how stash notifies Bamboo to perform a build, please consider more real time notifications to developers such as those using your SourceTree app.  SourceTree offers desktop notifications but the polling cycle is slow, in this era we have technologies to really improve this.

Thank you.

Neal Culiner
Stash 3.9.2 on Windows Server 2012
fields.summary: Send Remote Notifications to SourceTree when updates available

fields.description: The "Log selected..." context menu, which you can issue on a file in a specific commit, creates a log /only/ up to the time/date of this commit. It silently omits the whole history up to HEAD. It would be nice to see the whole log history, possibly graying out future commits in the table view to indicate that these entries are successors to the currently pinned commit.
fields.summary: The "Log selected..." context menu doesn't create a full log

fields.description: When selected multiple items in tree view, move option is not enabled.
fields.summary: Allow batch move of files

fields.description: When moving a single file by right clicking on the file and selecting 'Move', "Movinf" file is displayed in the output box.
fields.summary: Typo when moving single file

fields.description:
Repository logo/icon disappeared out of a sudden - possibly related to Bitbucket changing their Avatar URL returned via REST API recently. Attached is the image file of how it is showing currently.

Refreshing logo does not solve the issue.
fields.summary: Repository Logo/Icon in SourceTree for Mac Suddenly Stopped Showing.

fields.description: If master branch doesn't exist in the local repo, certain functions of GitFlow don't work properly (E.g: creating a release branch from 'Develop' branch)
fields.summary: GitFlow plugin is not working if master branch doesn't exist in the local repo

fields.description:
When trying to reverse a commit that was a merge, this error occurs:

{code}git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree revert --no-edit 80abf38c947ec6785453afc3da6723c563c0b6e1 
error: Commit 80abf38c947ec6785453afc3da6723c563c0b6e1 is a merge but no -m option was given.
fatal: revert failed
Completed with errors, see above{code}

Doing a reverse with the -m variable doesn't seem to be possible via GUI.
fields.summary: Reverse commit not working if the commit is a merged commit

fields.description:
h1. Replication:
Note: All redacted content will appear as xxxxxx.

# Add git repository in SourceTree
# Press the Terminal button in the toolbar (Image: http://i.imgur.com/VxJ4RBt.png)
# Add git subtrees using the following command in Terminal: 
{code:title=#!/bin/bash}
git subtree add --prefix modules/xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx https://xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx master
{code}
# Push branch to origin using Terminal:
{code:title=#!/bin/bash}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree push -v --tags origin refs/heads/feature/modules:refs/heads/feature/modules
{code}
# Quit the Terminal and reload the git repository in SourceTree
# Show 'SUBTREES' category in SourceTree sidebar

h1. Expected:
Should see a list of subtrees in the SourceTree sidebar

h1. Actual:
Did not see any subtrees in the SourceTree sidebar (Image: http://i.imgur.com/Z8Mvy7T.png)
The .git folder in the git repository has been attached. Note: All redacted content will appear as xxxxxx. The .git/objects folder has been deleted for security purposes.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not show git subtrees

fields.description:
When I uncheck "Allow SourceTree to modify your global Mercurial and Git configuration files" the external diff feature (e.g. hitting command-D) is still available in the UI but no longer works. Turning the option back on allows the feature to work again.

If the feature cannot be enabled, the options shouldn't be available (or should be disabled) in the UI. Also, it is not clear that permissions to modify the .gitconfig are required for the external diff feature to work (I eventually figured it out after a week of head scratching, the preferences panel for external diff does get disabled, but it is not clear why).

All that said, my .gitconfig still has the following (similar entries for merging, except the Kaleidoscope and SourceTree commands are the same for merge):

{noformat}
[diff]
	tool = Kaleidoscope
[difftool]
	prompt = false
[difftool "Kaleidoscope"]
	cmd = ksdiff --partial-changeset --relative-path \"$MERGED\" -- \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\"
[difftool "sourcetree"]
	cmd = /usr/local/bin/ksdiff -w \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\"
	path = 
{noformat}

If the difftool "sourcetree" section exists and is correct, shouldn't SourceTree just honor it and allow launching the external diff even if the the option to modify the config file is off? The preferences panel correctly identifies the correct difftool (just changing it is disabled).
fields.summary: External diff interactions with permission to modify config files

fields.description:
Issue: currently there are actions in SourceTree that report errors and abort the action, or just request user to perform something differently (and do abort the action). That is a "crack in UX", "rollback", or "flow breaker".

For example: I have cloned a project, made some modifications. Now, if I try to pull updates from repository (which was updated in the meantime), SourceTree will punish me with red error message:
{color:red}{noformat}
error: Your local changes to the following files would be overwritten by checkout:
	path/filename.ext
Please, commit your changes or stash them before you can switch branches.
Aborting
{noformat}{color}

And throws me back into main UI. That not only blocks the process, but also allows to try to make same mistake again, with the same result. Buttons are visible and enabled, even though it is known that pull/checkout will fail.
Now, instead of canceling my intention and throwing me back into main UI, it should offer available actions right away, in the same dialog, allowing to complete the pull/checkout process, or at least switch to different process immediately.
Does that make sense to you?
fields.summary: Allow smooth progression with no UX rollback.

fields.description:
When you are about to add files to the next commit, you have the staged files in the top and unstaged files in the bottom. Whenever you add a file of the unstaged files or remove on from the staged files, both file lists are freshed. Now the annoying thing happens, when either of this list is longer than the height of the subwindow so you have to scroll down.

Whenever you want to add or remove several files one after another which you only reach in the list after scrolling down, you have to scroll down again after each refresh and find the location where you left of. Sometimes SourceTree keeps the scroll position, but mostly it looses it and refreshing sometimes takes several seconds.

And to make it worse, when you scrolled down after the first refresh, sometimes a second refresh occurs and not only that you loose the position again, often the click on one file is happening on the file at the position of the mouse cursor after the fresh, ie. a completely different file. Then you have to remove it from the unstaged files again which causes additional work.

So it would be great, if SourceTree would at remember the approximate position within the file lists.
fields.summary: Keep original scroll location in unstaged files

fields.description: Often you end up stashing crap to clean up the workspace, however some of the content might be of value, but your workspace i not able to pop the stash because of other changes. Then it would be useful to be able to pick and choose hunks and lines directly out of the stash. Or simply keep stashes for later use by applying a tag, like git tag foo 'stash{0}'.
fields.summary: The possibility to apply individual hunks and tag a stash

fields.description:
There;s a way to start a Pull Request from the SourceTree App but there's no possibility to track them other than to spot if a branch is already merged or (as it is in my case, I'm using the rebase workflow) the corresponding remote branch has been removed from the origin.

Sometimes, when I do a lot of feature/fix branches I forgot to create a PR and some branach stays pushed to the origin (so I see 2 labels in the Log view) but up until I see no open Pull Requests in Stash and yet I still see those 2 labels in the Log view I won't realise the PR was not created.

The simple solution would be to mark the branches which have open Pull Requests in Stash some way.  Conceptually this could be achieved using Git tags. They shouldn't be listed in Tags sidebar section though. In fact I thought about marking my PRs this way manually but it turned out to be too much effort for the value gained ;)

It would be nice for the user to be able to navigate directly to the Pull Request overview from the SourceTree app, but I have no idea how this could be implemented - it's a rather non-Git feature.
fields.summary: Pull request might have been shown graphically

fields.description: Merge commits are displayed in light gray on bitbucket. I think it's a good idea that makes history very convenient to read.
fields.summary: "downlight" merge commits as done in bitbucket ?

fields.description: Is it possible have the $REPO variable parsed for the 'Script to run' field so that the script I'm referencing can be placed relative to the project repository?
fields.summary: Enable custom actions relative to repo.

fields.description:
Source code archeology makes a big part of day-to-day work and blame window is my main tool. But after switching from IDE window to blame dialog, I lose context and need to scroll down hundreds of lines of black-and-white code. If often miss the line I need and need to scroll back iteratively. For large files this is quite a painful process.

Syntax highlighting would definitely help to find needed line faster.

Also see related tickets that should also improve user experience in this case.
fields.summary: Syntax highlighting in blame window

fields.description:
sourcetree only allows searching for commit message, user, commit sha, and file modification contents. Even the latter option does not include the names of the modified files, so a search for 
helloworld.m 
would not find all the commits where helloworld.m was modified.

I think this feature is in pretty popular demand; a cursory search on your questions site provided me with two different asks for it:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/290210/how-do-i-search-a-commit-using-filename
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/11456979/file-search-in-sourcetree
fields.summary: Ability to search for filename (i.e. find all commits in which a certain file was modified)

fields.description: As you can see in the attachment there are multiple repositories with blank images (they have a custom image in bitbucket).
fields.summary: Custom Bitbucket repository image blank in sourcetree

fields.description: When the file HEAD in .git folder is locked, source tree is unable to change between branches, so you can't checkout to any other branch, and you have to manually edit the HEAD file and do a hard reset outside source tree.
fields.summary: Unable to checkout any branches

fields.description:
It would be nice, if there is an option which turns off the visual diff when selecting more than one file in the staging area.

Sometimes (mostly after refactorings) there are a lot of changes leading to longer time for calculating the visual diff. In this time you can't interact with source tree which interrupts the workflow.
fields.summary: New Option: Turn off visual diff when selection more than one file in the staging area

fields.description: When using Sourcetree on a mac that has another monitor attached, the correct window is not retained. If I start Sourcetree from built-in display and move it onto external one and then quit and try to start it from the built-in display, it will show again on the same (built-in) display (with correct position, just wrong display).
fields.summary: Window is not retained on multiscreen setup

fields.description:
Crash happens when remote repositories are refreshing:

Crash log:
{code}Process: SourceTree [45455]
Path: /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/MacOS/SourceTree

Responsible: SourceTree [45455]

30 com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS	0x000000010bb930bb 0x10bae7000 + 704699

4 com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS	0x000000010bb200db 0x10bae7000 + 233691

0x10bae7000 - 0x10bd8bff7 +com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS (2.0.3 - 2.0.3) <A784E90C-983A-3FDE-AFBE-E1D59786EA4B> /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/MacOS/SourceTree

fields.summary: SourceTree is reporting Perl crashes in _Core plugin

fields.description:
Hello,

I have a local repo open and I see the list of commits.  It would be nice if on the upper right was the Mac style searchbox that I could type text into and it would filter commit rows that contain that text helping me to find commits with commit messages containing that text.

Thanks
fields.summary: Add Mac OS X style search to search commit history text

fields.description:
Hello,

Git can get quite outdated, please add an option like on the Windows side to update embedded Git.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Add option to update embedded Git like in ST for Windows

fields.description: When reverting a merge commit, git requires "git revert -m". SourceTree doesn't account for this, and thus is unable to revert a merge commit.
fields.summary: "Reverse commit" function on a merge commit always fails

fields.description: Remotes should be sorted. In the screenshot, you can notice that "master" is after "coldfix", itself after "experiment": it makes no sense.
fields.summary: Remotes are unsorted

fields.description:
After tapping the Commit toolbar button (or hitting the menu item, etc.) when the Commit view appears, the commit message textbox should immediately take keyboard focus / become first responder.

Currently the top right search box takes first responder and i often begin typing my commit message in the search box. :(
fields.summary: On beginning a Commit, make commit message first responder.

fields.description:
On the history window, When right clicking on a revision and select 'Push revision 'XXXX', the push dialog that pops up has the correct revision specified. 

However, what actually gets pushed is the whole branch.
fields.summary: Unable to push single revision for Mercurial Repo

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
1. Initiate a drag of a file from the Finder.
2. Cross over top of a SourceTree repository browser window, but do not attempt to drop into SourceTree.

*Result:*
- SourceTree window pops to the foreground

*Expected:*
- SourceTree stays where it is in the window hierarchy.
fields.summary: When dragging to another app, over top of SourceTree, Sourcetree pops to foreground

fields.description: When creating or renaming a branch using standard branching (Repository > Branch...) , the text field for the new branch name does not substitute underscores for spaces. However, when using Git Flow and creating a new feature/hotfix/release branch, underscores are substituted for spaces in the new branch name.
fields.summary: Inconsistant underscore substitution for spaces when branching

fields.description:
Some of my projects lend themselves very well to the "flat list" and others to "tree view". It would be ideal if SourceTree could remember my preference on a per-project basis, rather than having this be a global setting.

For a precedent, consider Finder's folder view options (per-folder basis).
fields.summary: Per-project file/folder view settings

fields.description: Source tree sometimes fails to detect changes to local files. If I quit the app and restart, it detects the changes. Seems intermittent, or at least I haven't noticed a pattern.
fields.summary: Local changes not detected

fields.description:
I would appreciate a command line tool (or extension of existing tool) that would allow me to add a new repository, similar to the "File -> New" menu item or "New Repository" gui button, and also allow me to supply the details via the command line arguments (ie, batch mode).

This _should_ include support for setting the repository group where the repository bookmark will be saved.

eg,
{noformat}
stree clone ssh://git@stash/project/repository.git /path/local --name SubProject --group DomainGroup/AppProjects # .../etc
{noformat}

Resulting in SourceTree performing the clone (with optional path), and creating the bookmark without prompting the user for input (providing all relevant/required options are given).

And,
{noformat}
stree add /path/local --name SubProject --group DomainGroup/AppProjects # .../etc
{noformat}

Resulting in SourceTree creating the bookmark for the existing local repository without prompting the user for input (providing all relevant/required options are given).

Note: This should not open the repository, or at least allow for a batch mode/no-open argument.

The primary use case for this request is because puppet in my local environment has it's modules split into many repositories and many new modules/repositories can be created between the times I deal with the system. I currently have a script which I can run to inform me of new repositories (and their location details/etc), however I still have to add them to SourceTree by hand and it is becoming tedious.
fields.summary: Command line tool to add new repository

fields.description:
If you have a lot of remote repos on Stash ~ 120. Then Sourcetree won't show all the remote repos.

This issue occurs on systems running Yosemite (OS X 10.10) but does not occur on systems running earlier versions of OS X (such as 10.9) or on Windows.

There is also an issue of when you try to create a remote repo, you get a timeout popup:

!STtimeout.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Source Tree  doesn't show all remote repos from Stash

fields.description: Discard and remove are synonyms, so I would expect "Discard File" and "Remove File" to both delete the file from the repository, but that's not the case. Discard File actually removes the changes done to a file and therefor would be more aptly called "Remove Changes", "Discard Changes", "Revert Changes", or something similar. Please change the context menu for a file on the commit screen to have a more meaningful name.
fields.summary: Rename equivocal menu items Remove File / Discard File

fields.description: As of right now, it is very easy to check the "Bypass commit hooks" option when committing and forget to uncheck it on the next commit, sometimes resulting in code being committed that should have been caught by the commit hooks. I think the solution to this issue would be to either uncheck the option between each commit so that the user must choose to bypass it each time OR putting some sort of a highly visible alert or warning message directly above the commit message field letting the user know that it is still on. Currently, the only way you can tell whether this option is on is if you remember to click the "Commit options..." drop down menu that contains it before you commit.
fields.summary: Notification or warning that the "Bypass commit hooks" option is checked

fields.description: Sourcetree should behave better when a project is using Git Flow, and only allow pushing to a remote feature branch with the same name as the local feature branch when creating pull request from Sourcetree.
fields.summary: Create a Pull Request is misleading when used with Git Flow

fields.description:
# Change to Log View
# Click on an older commit
# Select a few lines of the diff on bottom right
# Right click

Expected result:
"Reverse lines" option in right click context menu

Actual result:
Only "Copy" is available
fields.summary: Reverse Line in context menu

fields.description:
Hello,

I've been using Git on our team a little over a month now moving from TFS on Windows and SVN on Mac into one system.  The atlassian stack is amazing, we have JIRA, Confluence, Fisheye/Crucible, Stash, and Bamboo all in play and love it!!!

Once concern we have with the SourceTree app is staying aware of remote changes such as developer pushes, etc.  I changed the default refresh from 10 to 5 minutes and may even lower it to 1 minute.  But it's hit or miss as to exactly when and what is required for the remote to be queried for updates.

Do I need to have the local remotes open? Do I just need the ST client app open?  It seems when the ST app is minimized to the Apple Dock at the bottom it's not querying until I restore it into view. 

I really would like to see a more aggressive polling of our remotes so we are always confident of when we have the latest pulled in or not.  I'd also suggest, if possible, like HipChat does, is the Stash server (or bitbucket) if tied to SourceTree to use remote/push notifications to send real time notifications to the client and subsequent show desktop notifications.

The Windows side needs the same attention in more aggressive polling but I prefer not to create another case if not needed.

Thank you for all of the great tools.  Please also continue to help us Git newbies create, use, and maintain submodules/subtrees by any automated push/pull's to ensure no bits ever get forgotten in managing source.  We don't use the submodules/trees yet as we're slowly learning Git so we need all of your help in the ST app to help us.

Neal
fields.summary: Faster remote refreshes and possibly push notification support

fields.description:
It would be nice, if SourceTree could fetch branches others then the active one.

Today you have to change into the branch and then you can pull it. But *git fetch origin master:master* does a fetch without the need to change into the *master* branch.
fields.summary: git fetch origin master:master

fields.description:
Is: Hitting the return key when navigating the repository list prompts user to rename the repository
Should be: Hitting the return key opens up the repository view, rename should be a contextual menu option
fields.summary: Repository Browser entries should open on Enter key press not rename

fields.description: When creating new repo on Sourcetree, after pasting Source URL, the destination path field will be filled in with the default destination path. However, if a user customise the path before the default destination path appears, the customised path will be replaced with the default destination path.
fields.summary: When creating new repo on Sourcetree, after pasting Source URL, don't apply default destination path if user already changed it

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
- Commit symlink to existing files (like in iOS frameworks).
- Push to remote.
- On another computer, pull changes.

Actual result:
Symlinks on another computer turn into plain text files.

Expeted result:
Symlinks should be created when pulled from remote.

Additional info:
When I commit/push/pull using Mercurial without Sourcetree, it works fine.
fields.summary: After pushing symlinks to Mercurial and pulling them, symlinks become plain text files

fields.description:
When searching for some commits, if a row with with a deleted file is selected, nothing will happen when trying to open the file. 

The option to open a deleted file should be disabled, or set to open the last existing state of such file.
fields.summary: The option to open a deleted file should be disabled

fields.description: Currently I can view commits from either all branches or a single branch. I would like to view selected branches - similar to hiding photoshop layers.
fields.summary: View only selected branches

fields.description: i would like the possibility to access the git-flow "finish feature" command from the commit panel, with a flag similar to the "push changes immediately". The flag should always be disabled by default, and the finish feature behaviour should be the "most used" one, for me is delete branch
fields.summary: access to git-flow "finish feature" from the commit panel, with a flag

fields.description:
Show list of  branches are completely included in a branch and also not included?

equivalent of -git branch --merged  and git branch --no-merged
fields.summary: List of  branches that are completely included in a branch and not included

fields.description:
We have a lot of branches in our repository. Right now, the branches combo box lists branches by their last use, with merged branches dropping below non-merged branches. This makes it difficult to find the specific branch in the drop down. Is it possible to sort the branch list alphabetically? TortoiseHG has this feature and it's much easier to use.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Please alphabetically sort the branch names in the branch combo box.

fields.description:
When having a local repo open on Sourcetree, when trying to add a remote for the local repo to be able to push it remotely, trying to create a new remote repo will cause Sourcetree to get stuck on "Please wait, your repository is being created now..."

Clinking 'Cancel' doesn't do anything. Only way to get Sourcetree usable again after getting stuck is by force quitting and restarting the app.

*Steps to Reproduce:*
 1) Open a local repo on Sourcetree
 2) Go to Repository settings, on the Remotes tab, choose to add a new remote
 3) Click the globe button to pick a URL/Path
 4) On the remote repo window, click 'Create New Repository'
 5) Enter a name of the repo and click 'Create Repository'

Sourcetree will get stuck after that and the repo isn't created on the remote host (Bitbucket,Github etc.)

When you cancel the request in SourceTree, you are getting the following error: 

"The operation couldn’t be completed. (com.google.GTMSessionFetcher error -1.)"
fields.summary: Trying to create a new remote repo will cause Sourcetree to get stuck

fields.description:
When having a local repo open on Sourcetree, when trying to add a remote for the local repo to be able to push it remotely, trying to create a new remote repo will cause Sourcetree to get stuck on "Please wait, your repository is being created now..."

Clinking 'Cancel' doesn't do anything. Only way to get Sourcetree usable again after getting stuck is by force quitting and restarting the app.

*Steps to Reproduce:*
1) Open a local repo on Sourcetree
2) Go to Repository settings, on the Remotes tab, choose to add a new remote
3) Click the globe button to pick a URL/Path
4) On the remote repo window, click 'Create New Repository'
5) Enter a name of the repo and click 'Create Repository'

Sourcetree will get stuck after that and the repo isn't created on the remote host (Bitbucket,Github etc.)
fields.summary: Trying to create a new remote repo will cause Sourcetree to get stuck

fields.description:
Trying to revert some changes via "Discard hunk".  The change was: a blank line that contained some trailing spaces into just a blank line (with no spaces).  This change came about from adding some debugging code and subsequently removing it (leaving a different blank line that was there before).

It appears that git-apply is refusing to apply the patch (to revert the change) because it would only add whitespace.

There's an option to git-apply to ignore this {noformat}--ignore-whitespace{noformat} or to deal with it {noformat}--whitespace=<action>{noformat} but SourceTree doesn't use those, or even expose them to me as a user to tell SourceTree that I want that option used.

The only work-around seems to be to go into the IDE and changes the lines myself, which defeats the purpose of using SourceTree in the first place...
fields.summary: Error 1, git apply, patch failed, trailing whitespace

fields.description:
Interactive rebase workflow is such that accidentally reordering the commits or otherwise bolloxing up the work is FAR TOO EASY.

Here's a better workflow:

Select a range of commits e.g. with mouse click.

Popup menu -> "Squash N commits"

done.

/*****************************/

After farting around some more with current squashing workflow, I find some VERY ANNOYING and seemingly stupid things:

1. After a few "squash with previous" clicks, all of which seemed to take OK, I finish with the interactive sheet.
2. I get some utterly obscure message "could not squash commit abc123....." . Fine, whatever.
3. At this point the squash workflow is bolloxed up. I can't commit, I can't continue, I can't undo. Any action I take (if it has meaningful action) just pops up the same "could not squash commit abc123....". 
4. If I try another interactive rebase (BTW, the popup and main menu states at this point are OUT OF SYNC -- one is live, the other is disabled), I get a somewhat less obscure message "hmmm, looks like you are in the middle of a rebase already, so I won't do anything, but you can 'rm -rf /path/to/.git/rebase/folder' and then try again".
5. I don't have any obvious workflow that would force the squash or abort or fix it or ANYTHING.

SO, here's how it should work.

If I squash or attempt to squash a commit and git isn't going to like it, THEN YOU SHOULD BLOCK THE ACTION AND LET ME KNOW RIGHT AWAY, e.g. give me buttons like "OK, wrap up this squash" or "abort this squash" or "omit this commit from squash".

If there is some obscure git reason that some commit is unacceptable, YOU SHOULD INCLUDE SOME MEANINGFUL INFO ABOUT WTF IS GOING ON, AND HOW TO GET AROUND IT, OR WHY IT'S A BAD THING TO DO, etc.

more complaints later. I would like this workflow to work easily and smoothly.

/*****************************/

amending the above use case with one commit that git (or Sourcetree) doesn't like,  in the midsts of several other commits that are (presumably) A-OK to squash.

For commits {0 .. N-1}, N, {N+1 .. M} where N is the commit that causes grief, JUST SQUASH THE FIRST SET AND THE FINAL SET. LEAVE "N" IN PLACE UNSQUASHED.
fields.summary: Interactive rebase feature is VERY clunky.

fields.description:
I have an Hg-flow repo with a feature branch of it which has commits and shows nothing uncommitted (ie. clean working directory). If I then create a new branch (normal branch, not hg-flow) off the hg-flow feature branch, the branch is created OK, but the graph part at the top says "Uncommitted changes", although the detail pane below it shows "Nothing to commit".

Why is it showing Unommitted changes ?
fields.summary: Branch off Hg-Flow Feature branch - Sourcetree shows Uncommitted changes, but also says nothing to commit

fields.description: I regularly work with many repositories opened and it opens one window for each instead of managing them in tabs. I think having tab would be a simple solution and would be way better!
fields.summary: Create tabs instead of windows for each repository

fields.description: For documenting progress in online project management tools, it would be very handy to be able to copy a commit's remote url on Bitbucket / Github to clipboard via a context menu
fields.summary: context menu option to copy remote commit url

fields.description:
This looks like the same problem as SRCTREE-2900, but upgrading to the latest beta has not fixed the issue. I cannot perform any mercurial operations. Trying to open an hg repo throws an error (screenshots attached). Similar error shows up in the perferences pane for mercurial. 

Disabling hgsubversion extension did not fix the problem.
fields.summary: 2.0.5.2b0 hg still broken - 'hg log' failed with code 1

fields.description:
When "Date Order" is used on the commit graph, it displays the commits in the wrong order and the lines do not reflect the actual branches anymore.

This creates problems after the commit order is changed via interactive rebase.
fields.summary: Commit graph broken with "Date Order"

fields.description:
I love the search function very much!

But I found that there's no search history.
It would be great to have such feature, though it's quite minor ;)

Cheers!
fields.summary: Search History Improvement

This is Error Message when I click on my repo in the Repository Browser:

fields.description: Add an option to push to multiple repositories at once. Similar to push to push to multiple branches but for origins.
fields.summary: Push to multiple repos

fields.description:
Sometimes it would be very helpful to view the history of changes to a file. I think this would involve a new view, because the current one is very much oriented toward seeing the files & changes in a commit. I imagine being able to right-click on any file in the current view, select "View File History", and get a window which lists all the commits of changes to the file, so that one could quickly click through the commit history and see the diffs made at each commit.

And, for me, the real killer feature would be to then be able to right-click a commit, select "merge with current", and be able to immediately be taken to the file diff/merge application (usually BBEdit) with the current (either tip or uncommitted) version and the version in that commit. In other words, retrieve the version from that commit into a temporary location, then diff it with the current one in the repository.

These two features would go a long way toward making it easy to deal with branch merges that have conflicts, and/or picking out changes from a branch to back-patch.
fields.summary: history of changes to file

fields.description:
Similar to how you can stage code on a per-line basis, it would be nice to be able to go through a commit log and "split" it into multiple commits.  For example, if I accidentally commit a file that has two fixes, it would be nice to go in to the commit log, and select which lines you want to be pulled out of the original commit and added as a second commit.

Understandably, this would modify the commit history - similar to appending a commit or rebasing.  It might be good to have a similar "warning" for the user about the history being modified.

I don't know if Git proper has the ability to do this, but I have been able to achieve this same end result through creative use of the SourceTree "reverse lines/hunk/file", "append previous commit" and "rebase children interactively"...but it would be nice to have some sort of UI-based way of doing this.
fields.summary: Ability to "split" commits

fields.description: When using interactive rebase to edit a commit message. The new commit message dialog appears to omit any text that occurs after the first line break. I tried searching the issue tracker, but didn't find anything related. Hopefully this is not a duplicate report.
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase Commit Message & New Line

fields.description:
Seems there's a problem with the build.

Probably need to deal with symbolic links correctly.

mymac-4 /Applications $ ll SourceTree.app//Contents/Frameworks/Sparkle.framework/Versions/A/Resources/fr_CA.lproj
lrwxr-xr-x 1 me admin 110 Feb  3 10:34 SourceTree.app//Contents/Frameworks/Sparkle.framework/Versions/A/Resources/fr_CA.lproj -> /Users/andym/Development/Build Products/Release (GC dual-mode; 10.5-only)/Sparkle.framework/Resources/fr.lproj
fields.summary: Sourcetree 2.0.5.2 has symbolic link to /Users/andym/...

fields.description:
I'm moving the branch pointer to another commit and get presented with an alert sheet that says "Are you sure you want to move the branch pointer?". 

The commit message of the chosen commit needs to be word wrapped in this alert. Right now, it is shown on a single line, so if the message is long, it causes the alert to be wider than the screen! See screenshot.
fields.summary: Alert sheet presents commit message on single line, causing insanely wide alerts.

fields.description: When I add files to the staging area and then hit ⇧⌘C (shortcut for commit selected files), the diff I'm shown is for uncommitted files. It would be nice if we have a shortcut or a settings to diff the committed files, as to aid writing the commit messages.
fields.summary: See diff of committed file while writing a commit

fields.description:
When trying to add a symlink to the repository, staging will fail, showing the error message {{fatal: pathspec '<path to symlink>' did not match any files}}

The symlink can be added from the 'git add' command on command line without issues. Committing works as expected.
fields.summary: Unable to add a symlink on Sourcetree

fields.description:
not found!
real URL is http://123.103.9.60:7002/
abort: HTTP Error 500: Internal Server Error
fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
fatal: unable to access 'http://123.103.9.60:7002/svn/': The requested URL returned error: 500
Redirecting to URL 'http://123.103.9.60:7002':
svn: E175002: Unable to connect to a repository at URL 'http://123.103.9.60:7002'
svn: E175002: The OPTIONS request returned invalid XML in the response: XML parse error at line 1: no element found (http://123.103.9.60:7002)
fields.summary: can't create repository via visualsvn server url

fields.description:
This issue seems to only happen on private instances. (E.g: Github Enterprise, Stash)

If the password contains an equals sign, '=', access over HTTP will always prompt to enter password on Sourcetree, sometimes twice.

Using the Keychain Access app, there's an entry under the private instance server name. However, the stored password is truncated where the equal sign should be. Manually entering the full password there in Keychain Access works around the issue.
fields.summary: Passwords containing '=' are not saved to keychain correctly

fields.description:
A user said:

"The current branch of the working copy is not obvious enough in the GUI.

Maybe change the "Staged files" label to "Staged files (branch name)" or something else to raise the prominence of the branch."
fields.summary: Request: Change the "Staged files" label to "Staged files (branch name)"

fields.description:
From SourceTree:

https://stash.example.com/projects/foo/repos/bar/pull-requests?create&sourceBranch=feature%2Fjrencz%2Ffoo+bar

From Stash itself:

https://stash..example.com/projects/foo/repos/bar/pull-requests?create&sourceBranch=refs%2Fheads%2Ffeature%2Fjrencz%2Ffoo%2Bbar&targetBranch=refs%2Fheads%2Fdevelop
fields.summary: When "+" is used in branch name it's not escaped after "Create pull request..." is used

fields.description:
When adding a new file, there is only one button "stage hunk". When adding a hunk from an existing  file, there are two buttons "stage hunk" and "discard hunk". Because of this, when staging hunks, when I go from a new file to an existing file with code changes, without moving the mouse it switches from "stage hunk" to "discard hunk", and I can easily accidentally delete my changes.

To fix, I would propose the "Stage hunk" button to always be the far right; so without moving your mouse it remains there.
fields.summary: UX: inconsistent "stage hunk" button location

fields.description:
The "Locked" file attribute is a Mac-only setting you can set or reset in the Finder (using the get-info command on the file/directory). It is NOT making the file/directory "ReadOnly". It only prevents the user from dragging the item to the trash, and empty the trash.  When set for a directory, it has no effect on the contents (files and directories) within that directory.

I use it on the repository directory, to ensure I don't delete it by mistake. All development tools (and Git!) work fine on this repository.

However - if I try to resolve a merge conflict using external merge tool (no matter what tool is chosen in the preferences) it fails - because git fails to create the _LOCAL, _REMOTE, _BASE versions of the conflicted file. They simply are not created. 

This is NOT a "readonly" problem, because git DOES create the .orig and _BACKUP versions of that same file.

Of course the external merge tool, when launched, fails to find the files to merge, and fails.

Resetting the "Locked" attribute on the repository removes the problem.

This is not strictly a SourceTree problem, because using the "git mergetool" command from the terminal yields similar results. However, SourceTree comes with git embedded, and it might be in your interest to resolve the issue.

This is a NEW issue, as I worked fine before with the "Locked" flag set for my repositories, but I can't tell WHEN the problem started.
fields.summary: If Repository directory is "Locked" (Mac-only file attribute), resolving conflicts using external merge tool is not possible.

fields.description:
Despite it being called Optional Extended Integration and shouldn't have the need to fill up anything in that section, editing Remote Details in Repository Settings without filling up Host Root URL will cause a crash/hang.

The only workaround to stop the crash, is to change the Host Type to Unknown as described here:

!host.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Editing Remote Details in Repository Settings without filling up Host Root URL will cause a crash/hang

fields.description:
In branches view, there's several interesting options, but it seems it's not possible to visualize all local branches + their "state" on remotes repos, +without+ having all remote branches.

Working in a feature-branching team, there _lots_ of remote branches. Only the ones I'm working on interest me.

I can see my current branch + its remote states (for one branch...). Or all branches, including remote ones. But I can't have my several local branches + the remote ones they are tracking. If I want to, I currently suffer the noise of other remotes branches I don't care about.
fields.summary: Show all local branches + tracked-only remote branches

fields.description:
When opening a project, looking at a branch, the filename/path/commit message panel is very narrow next to the difference window.
After resizing the panel so I can see everything, the resize information is lost when the window is closed and re-opened.
fields.summary: Commit Panel size lost on close

fields.description: It would be nice, when writing a commit message if you could select a word or a phrase and then press `, ' or " and it would wrap the selection in the quote.
fields.summary: Quote when selected

fields.description:
1) Commit something
2) Update to any revision but the one you want to strip
3) Strip the revision and make sure to check the keep changes box
4)You just lost all your hard work

Aside from this terrible bug, I can't believe I have to remember checking a box in order to not loose my changes! Default option should be not loosing them
fields.summary: Changes lost when "stripping from here" while on a different revision than the one being stripped

fields.description:
When githook script  shebang looks as following: 
#!/bin/sh
':' //; exec "$(command -v nodejs || command -v node)" "$0" "$@"
an 'exec: command not found' is reported into a console.

Being running, the script works fine.
$git commit ran in a shell console also works fine.

Another shebang
#!/usr/bin/env node
produces a similar result: 'node: command not found'

There is a workaround with a soft link to node as '/usr/bin/node', but when Node is managed with nvm, this way is unacceptable. The soft link also worked for a simple node installation, with the same error when the link was not created.

SourceTree must spawn a git command in the same environment as this command is ran from a shell console.
fields.summary: User environment is not considered when git process is spawned

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
1) Tag a commit on Sourcetree and push tag into remote repo.
2) On Sourcetree, right click the existing tag, check the "Push tag" option and select the repository, open advanced options and check "Move existing tag"
3) When clicking add, an error message stating that the tag already exists on the server will occur.

Workaround: 
Select only "move existing tag", but NOT "Push tag", then use the git command line to execute:
{{git push origin --tags -f}}
fields.summary: Moving git tag with "Push tag" option checked will cause error ''tag already exists on the server'.

fields.description:
When you create a pull request from the sourcetree client, it redirects you bitbucket and starts creating a pull request there. Unfortunately, it always sets the destination to master, which is rarely the case. Sometimes people will forget to change that destination, which could lead to people accidentally merging changes into master without going through development branches. I think it should be smarter.

Possible solutions:
* It could search back through its commits to find the latest commit that's also on another branch, and set that as the destination. When you create a pull request from the web client, it seems to do something like that.
* Simply default to dev or development, checking that they exist, before defaulting to master
fields.summary: Create Pull Request should set destination appropriately instead of using master

fields.description: Branch colors are nice and all, but I would sure like to be able to set preferred colors.  I use a master branch and dev branch everywhere and I would like to be able to use common colors for each of those across repositories.
fields.summary: Allow customization of branch colors
